prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will observe the (2-1) transitions of CO, 13CO, and C18O at ~100 AU resolution using 0.1 km/s channels (similar to Tobin et al. 2012). The C18O and 13CO (J=2-1) lines will be observed in the same base-band with half the band to each line and observing in a 60 MHz bandwidth and 0.083 km/s velocity, which is necessary to map the Keplerian motion of the disks. The 12CO (J=2-1) line will be observed in the full band with a 117 MHz bandwidth and 0.08 km/s channels. In addition, we are using 2 basebands for 1.3 mm continuum emission with a total of 4GHz of bandwidth to detect the compact dust emission in the sources.
Our time estimates are based our previous detections of CO isotopologues in Class 0 sources in published results and ongoing CARMA surveys (out of 6 objects 3 show hints of Keplerian at 300 AU size-scale so higher resolution follow-ups are being done). The time estimate is driven by the sensitivity requirement for the C18O (J=2-1) observations, which is 30 mJy/beam in a 0.1 km/s velocity channel (or ~3K) and give us S/N of 4 to 10. This sensitivity, with binning in weaker cases, will provide detections and allow for Keplerian fits.
Perseus sources are at a distance if 230 pc, which gives a spatial resolution of 115 AU with 0.5". The declination of Perseus is about 31 degrees (max. elevation 36 degrees), but easily observed at ALMA.

We will observe the (2-1) transitions of CO, 13CO, and C18O at ~100 AU resolution using 0.1 km/s channels (similar to Tobin et al. 2012). The C18O and 13CO (J=2-1) lines will be observed in the same base-band with half the band to each line and observing in a 60 MHz bandwidth and 0.083 km/s velocity, which is necessary to map the Keplerian motion of the disks. The 12CO (J=2-1) line will be observed in the full band with a 117 MHz bandwidth and 0.08 km/s channels. In addition, we are using 2 basebands for 1.3 mm continuum emission with a total of 4GHz of bandwidth to detect the compact dust emission in the sources.
Our time estimates are based our previous detections of CO isotopologues in Class 0 sources in published results and ongoing CARMA surveys (out of 6 objects 3 show hints of Keplerian at 300 AU size-scale so higher resolution follow-ups are being done). The time estimate is driven by the sensitivity requirement for the C18O (J=2-1) observations, which is 30 mJy/beam in a 0.1 km/s velocity channel (or ~3K) and give us S/N of 4 to 10. This sensitivity, with binning in weaker cases, will provide detections and allow for Keplerian fits.
The distance for these sources is not well known, ranging from 200-450 pc, which gives a spatial resolution of 100 to 225 AU with 0.5".

We will observe the (2-1) transitions of CO, 13CO, and C18O at ~100 AU resolution using 0.1 km/s channels (similar to Tobin et al. 2012). The C18O and 13CO (J=2-1) lines will be observed in the same base-band with half the band to each line and observing in a 60 MHz bandwidth and 0.083 km/s velocity, which is necessary to map the Keplerian motion of the disks. The 12CO (J=2-1) line will be observed in the full band with a 117 MHz bandwidth and 0.08 km/s channels. In addition, we are using 2 basebands for 1.3 mm continuum emission with a total of 4GHz of bandwidth to detect the compact dust emission in the sources.
Our time estimates are based our previous detections of CO isotopologues in Class 0 sources in published results and ongoing CARMA surveys (out of 6 objects 3 show hints of Keplerian at 300 AU size-scale so higher resolution follow-ups are being done). The time estimate is driven by the sensitivity requirement for the C18O (J=2-1) observations, which is 30 mJy/beam in a 0.1 km/s velocity channel (or ~3K) and give us S/N of 4 to 10. This sensitivity, with binning in weaker cases, will provide detections and allow for Keplerian fits.
The new distance for Serpens is 415 pc, which gives a spatial resolution of 200 AU with 0.5".

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent observations have detected Keplerian motion on ~100 AU size-scales in two Class 0 disks (L1527 and VLA 1623) in 13CO and C18O, providing the first directly measured masses of the youngest protostars. These results show that we can use CO isotopologues to probe the disk forming regions of Class 0 sources and reveal Keplerian motions. Although these molecules have been observed in other surveys without clear Keplerian signatures, the ability to probe ~100 AU size-scales, resolve out large-scale emission, and separate the outflow from the inner-envelope has been the key in the two successes to date. Building on these successes, we propose a snapshot CO (2-1) isotopologic survey of 26 Class 0 protostars. With these data, we will be able to find more Keplerian Class 0 disks, allowing a probe of the evolution of circumstellar disks and a constraint on theoretical models of disk origins.
